name: The KLF
bio: Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty’s lasting artistic legacy comes not just from their iconic LPs, but from their anarchic approach to promotion and culture-jamming, such as burning one million pounds sterling on television in 1994.

children.name: The Orb
children.bio: One of the most influential groups in the history of contemporary electronic music, pioneers of ambient house and with several records from their early ’90s purple patch hailed as touchstones of the chill out genre.

children.name: Steve Hillage
children.bio: An English guitarist who founded ’70s prog rock and jazz fusion bands, Khan and Gong, and wrote and produced solo albums of experimental ambient music.

children.name: System 7
children.bio: A collab between Steve Hillage and French keyboard player and vocalist Miquette Giraudy, featuring special guests like Derrick May, Laurent Garnier and Carl Craig.

children.name: Mixmaster Morris
children.bio: An English DJ, radio host and music journalist specializing in the “chill out” sound. In addition, he released solo albums on labels such as Rising High and Ninja Tune.

children.name: Mira Calix
children.bio: A Durban-born, London-based composer that has written several solo albums for Warp Records, scoring orchestral soundtracks for films, theatrical performances and gallery installations.

children.name: Aphex Twin
children.bio: One of the pioneers of contemporary British experimental electronic music, mixing downtempo breakbeats into ambient techno and abstracted jungle. Often labelled as IDM.

children.name: The Black Dog
children.bio: A UK techno trio who have released records since the early 1990s. In 2010, they released a response to Brian Eno’s seminal 1970s work, entitled Music For Real Airports.

children.name: Move D
children.bio: A German DJ and producer who has worked within ambient and techno since the early 1990s. Collabs include Deep Space Network and Magic Mountain High.

children.name: HIA
children.bio: HIA is an abbreviation of Higher Intelligence Agency, the ambient alias of British Bobby Bird, who released three seminal LPs via the Beyond label in the early ’90s as well as collaborating with Pete Namlook and Biosphere.

children.name: Reagenz
children.bio: Reagenz is Move D and Jonah Sharp, AKA Spacetime Continuum. They have worked together for decades, with 20 years elapsing between their debut self-titled LP and 2014’s The Periodic Table.

children.name: Tetsu Inoue
children.bio: Closely aligned to the sound of Brian Eno, this ambient Japanese producer has created over 20 full-length releases since the early 1990s.

children.name: Mr. YT
children.bio: Alias of Japanese producer Yuji Takenouchi, who released three EPs exclusively via Belgian labels between 1997 and 1998.

children.name: Coldcut
children.bio: Jonathan More and Matt Black’s collage-like sampling saw them hailed as one of the pioneering groups of the ’80s and ’90s hip hop and dance music crossover scene.

children.name: DJ Food
children.bio: Originally a Coldcut side project, DJ Food evolved into a live project of Patrick Carpenter and Kevin Foakes, AKA Strictly Kev, releasing five volumes of the Jazz Brakes series between 1990 and 1994.

children.name: NTone Records
children.bio: A Ninja Tune side label, NTone existed from 1994 until 2001 releasing records by the likes of Neotropic, Si Begg and Flanger (Atom TM + Brunt Friedman).

children.name: Deep Space Network
children.bio: Experimental ambient techno project featuring producer and DJ Move D and Jonas Grossmann. Influences included progressive rock, easy listening pop and jazz.

children.name: Rising High
children.bio: A key British label in the growth of the ’90s ambient techno and chill out styles, releasing hundreds of records throughout the ’90s from the likes of Mixmaster Morris, Luke Vibert and The Hypnotist.

children.name: Pete Namlook
children.bio: Wildly prolific German producer and founder of experimental electronic label FAX, renowned for his collaborations with the likes of Move D., Atom TM., Richie Hawtin and Biosphere.

children.name: Fax Records
children.bio: Founded by Pete Namlook under the official name FAX +49-69/450464 in 1992, this label mainly released Namlook’s solo and collaborative productions and had three sub-labels, including the vast catalog of Atom TM’s Rather Interesting.

children.name: WAU! Mr. Modo
children.bio: An enormously influential ambient label founded by Alex Paterson and Youth. Many of the most well-known releases by the Orb first appeared here.

children.name: Thomas Fehlmann
children.bio: An artist bridging multiple generations of ambient music, dating back to his days as a member of the Orb up to and including work on his own label Teutonic Beats and recent releases via Kompakt and Editions Mego.

children.name: Sun Electric
children.bio: A group composed of Tom Thiel and Max Loderbauer, who first released via WAU! Mr. Modo before beginning a career-long collaboration with R&S. The duo are considered key innovators of IDM.

children.name: FFWD
children.bio: Something of an ambient all-star team, composed of Robert Fripp, Thomas Fehlmann, Kris Weston and Alex Paterson.

children.name: Tom Green / Baku
children.bio: A frequent collaborator of the Orb. His sole release under the Baku alias was 1990’s Desert Fresh EP on WAU! Mr. Modo.

children.name: Another Fine Day
children.bio: An alias of Tom Green, with notable releases on the UK’s influential Beyond label and Canada’s Interchill.

children.name: Youth
children.bio: The original bassist in Killing Joke, co-producer of the Orb’s seminal ‘Adventures Beyond...’ and co-founder of the WAU! Mr. Modo record label alongside Alex Paterson.

children.name: The Fireman
children.bio: A collaboration between Youth and Paul McCartney of the Beatles, together creating primarily downtempo psychedelic electronic music.
